_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Van Buskirk Fertilizer
P.O. Box 778
Ringling, Okla. 73456

For futher information contact:Owner (580)662-2447

Risk Management Plan- EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1. The Facility Policy

The owners, management of Van Buskirk Fertilizer, Ringling, Oklahoma are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire dept. or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

2. Facility Information

Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application and for crop production
nutrients. 
The Maximum quantity stored would be 78,795 pounds in our 18,000 gallon storage tank. Due to the rounding requirements of the RMP Submit Program, the 78,795 pounds is rounded to 80,000 pounds.

3. The worst-case release scenario and the alternative scenario.

a. The worst-case release scenario would be the release of the total contents of the storage tank released as a gas over 10 minutes. The maximum quantity release would be 78,795 pounds, which represents the
volume of the storage tank at 85 percent capacity as limiled by design standards. The distance to the 
endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is 2.4 miles.

b. The alternative release scenario based on the most likely potential incident is a release from a break in a transfer hose. The distance to the endpoint (Point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is .83 miles.

4. The accidental release prevention program

The facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, Kk-611.1", published by The Aamerican National Standards Institute, Inc., and
the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29CFR 1910.111, 
"Storage and handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".

5. The Five-year Accident History

a. There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the

past five years that:
Have caused any deaths, injuries or significant propety damage at the facility nor 
To our knowledge,  have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property 
damage, or environmental damage.

6. The Emergency Response Program

The facility has;
. 
a. A written Emergency Action Plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910:38;

b. Provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information
as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA) ;

c.A written emergency response program, in accordance with OSHA standard 29 CFR 1910.120 including pre-emergency planning and employee training.

7. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. Safety improvement is  an on-going process at the facility. There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
